Two Republican presidential candidates who oppose President Obama's plan to accept 10,000 Syrian refugees stretched the facts to support their policy position:

• Ben Carson said that the majority of Syrian refugees are "young males." But the United Nations' figures show women outnumber men, and children 11 years old and younger, male and female, account for 38.5% of all refugees.

• Scott Walker said that "many" of the refugees who have been admitted to the United States this fiscal year came from Syria. Actually, Syrians represent just 2.3% of the 57,350 total global refugees accepted by the U.S. as of Aug. 31.
'Majority' of Syrian Refugees Are 'Young Males'?

Carson, a retired neurosurgeon, made the claim during an interview on CNN's The Lead with John Berman. Carson said he didn't think the United States should be willing to take in more Syrian refugees, arguing that the risk of some refugees actually being terrorists was too great.

Carson is entitled to his opinion about whether the United States should allow more Syrian refugees to enter the country, and we take no position on that. But his comment that "the majority of them are young males" is contradicted by the best data available on the Syrian refugees' demographics.

The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees — which refers refugees for resettlement in other countries — says there are more than 4 million registered Syrian refugees. Its figures on the demographic makeup of refugees is based on available data on the 2.1 million who were registered by the UNHCR in Egypt, Iraq, Jordan and Lebanon. (Another 1.9 million Syrian refugees were registered by the Government of Turkey, and more than 24,000 were registered in North Africa.)
UNHCR's data show that 50.5% of refugees are women. Females age 18 to 59 make up 23.9% of the refugees, while males in that age group make up 21.8%.

Even younger males — age 12 to 17 — represent 6.5% of refugees, while females that age are 6.1%. The majority of refugees — 51.1% — are under age 17, including 38.5% who are younger than 12 years old. These numbers were as of Sept. 6.

We have seen a different set of UNHCR numbers cited on a few conservative websites — figures for refugees and migrants who have tried to enter Europe by crossing the Mediterranean Sea. There have been more than 400,000 such "sea arrivals" in 2015, and 51% are Syrian. The rest have come mainly from nine other countries. Most of these refugees and migrants have been men — 72% — but these are not figures on Syrian refugees or even solely the 200,000-some Syrians who have been willing to take some type of boat to reach Europe by sea.

In the CNN interview, Carson also implied that the U.S. would take in much higher numbers of Syrian refugees than the 10,000 the Obama administration has said the country would accept in fiscal 2016. Carson said, "I will tell you that if I was ISIS, I were the global jihadist and I knew the United States was about to take in 10,000 or 65,000 or 100,000 people from my region, I would infiltrate them with my people."

As we wrote in an Ask FactCheck on this topic, a humanitarian aid group and a group of Democratic senators have argued that the U.S. should accept 65,000 Syrians in 2016 — which is half of the number the United Nations had identified for resettlement worldwide by the end of that year. But so far, the Obama administration hasn't committed to anything close to that.

On Sept. 10, the White House announced it would accept at least 10,000 Syrian refugees in fiscal 2016, which begins Oct. 1. White House spokesman Josh Earnest said it would take 12 to 18 months to complete the resettlement process, which includes "security precautions," so not all of them will be in the U.S. before the next fiscal year ends Sept. 30, 2016.

One last thing: Carson also exaggerates when he says that once the U.S. accepts 10,000 Syrian refugees "then you have got to bring other members of the family in. So you're multiplying that number substantially."

The U.S. refugee program allows certain family members of refugees to apply for refugee status, but that "does not guarantee acceptance," as the State Department explains on its website. Among other things, the U.S. sets priorities on the type of refugees it will accept, and family reunification is the third of three priorities. As the Congressional Research Services says in a Feb. 18 report, the top priority is given to "persons facing compelling security concerns," not family members.

As for Carson's claim that Syrian family members would increase the overall number of Syrian refugees "substantially," we cannot say whether that would happen. But we note that the president each year places a limit on the number of all refugees, including family members, by region.
U.S. Has Accepted 'Many' Syrian Refugees?
Walker made his remarks about Syrian refugees on CNN's State of the Union, where anchor Jake Tapper noted Obama's plan to accept 10,000 Syrian refugees and asked Walker why he opposes it.

As of Aug. 31, the U.S. had accepted 1,293 Syrian refugees in fiscal 2015, which ends Sept. 30, according to figures from the State Department's Refugee Processing Center. That's 2.3% of the 57,350 total global refugees that the U.S. has accepted this fiscal year.

Obama had authorized the State Department for fiscal year 2015 to accept as many as 70,000 refugees from around the world, including 33,000 from Near East/South Asia, which includes Syria. Since 2011, when the Syrian civil war began, the U.S. has accepted nearly 1,500 Syrian refugees. That total could rise to 1,800 by the end of September, a State Department spokesman told us.
Although an increase of an additional 10,000 Syrian refugees would be substantial, it's less than what some other countries have committed to accept or have already accepted.

Since 2013, Germany has committed to accepting 35,000 Syrian refugees, and Canada has committed to 11,300, according to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. (The UN agency has submitted 18,336 Syrian refugees to the U.S. for its consideration, but as we mentioned that's more than the U.S. has said that it would accept.)

In addition, "many more refugees have moved spontaneously [outside the country to other nations] and have been granted asylum or are in the process of having their claims assessed," Ariane Rummery of the UNHCR told us in an email.

Rummery provided us with data that showed Germany has received nearly 40,000 new asylum applications from Syrians in the first seven months of 2015, and Hungary has received nearly 11,000 in the first six months. The U.S. has received just 545 in the first seven months of 2015, the data show.
Contributing: Eugene Kiely
LAKEWOOD - Republican presidential candidate Dr. Ben Carson stopped by Colorado Christian University Thursday morning.

Carson was invited to talk to the students as a part of its Distinguished Speaker Series. He spoke about his underprivileged life growing up and how his mother, who had only a third grade-level education, encouraged him to pursue his dream of becoming a doctor.
Wednesday night he faced off with other GOP candidates at CU Boulder. Before his talk to the students, he expressed his disappointment with the debate moderators.

"Debates are supposed to be established to help the people get to know the candidates and get to know what's behind them and what's their thinking process is, what their philosophy is. And what it's turned into is a 'gotcha,'" said Carson.

The presidential candidate said he asked his staff to reach out to the other Republicans in hopes of changing the format of future debates. He wants to allow presidential hopefuls to lay out their plans, then be questioned.
Republican presidential nominee Dr. Ben Carson will do two fundraising events on his visit to Middle Tennessee Saturday with a private event also scheduled in the afternoon in Belle Meade.
The reception is scheduled at 1:30-3 p.m. at the home of Ellen Martin. A VIP reception and photo opportunity will be from 1-1:30 p.m.
Carson, who has accelerated his position as a front-runner for the GOP nomination, also has a morning reception titled Coffee and Conversation at 9-10:30 a.m. at the home of Franklin Mayor Ken Moore.
Cost to attend either event is $1,000 per person, which includes the general reception. Both events also offer a host level for $2,700 per person.
To RSVP visit www.bencarson.com/franklin or www.bencarson.com/nashville.
For information email Thomsen Smith at GOP@thomsensmith.com.
Reach Andy Humbles at 615-726-5939 and on Twitter @ AndyHumbles.
Ben Carson on guns
I agree completely with Ben Carson when he says more people should be armed with guns ("Ben Carson suggests more people should be armed").
As Wayne LaPierre, executive vice president of the National Rifle Association, said after the Newtown, Conn., massacre: “The only thing that stops a bad guy with a gun, is a good guy with a gun.”

I think it’s time Americans took their collective heads out of the sand and realized that the police can’t get there fast enough, and the useless politicians won’t enact laws to save you because they're too busy disagreeing with each other. Maybe if a good guy with a gun shoots the next bad guy, other would-be shooters will think twice.
Rob Siragusa; Hartford, Conn.
Remember the victims
Today, and in general, I have zero tolerance for:
•Discourse about why our military shouldn’t be in Afghanistan instead of prayers for the families of those who died there in a U.S. bombing last week.
•Debates about how guns cause shootings/stop shootings instead of compassion for those who didn’t know they were saying goodbye for the last time before the Oregon community college massacre.
•Talk about how President Obama/Hillary Clinton/Republicans/fill-in-the-blank are the root cause of the evils in our country instead of a feeling of joint responsibility for fixing what’s broken.
For one day, to start, can we remember that these aren’t just news stories or sound bites? That there are people behind the stories?
Randi S. Cairns; Brunswick, N.J.
Dr. Ben Carson meet Horatio Alger. He was a prolific writer of the 19th century. Alger's most famous works are the tales of "rags to riches," impoverished youth who made it big in their adulthood.

Alger consistently wrote of poor lower socio-economic youth growing up in cities in which the youth, through hard work, thrift, discipline, and diligence made it big. They pulled themselves up by their own bootstraps. Despite their impoverished circumstances and possible excuses, these Alger's youth would have none of that, and chose to be successful adults. Alger, if alive today, would be writing about Carson.

The longer the presidential campaign goes on, the more Americans like him. The longer the campaign goes on, the more voters love Dr. Ben Carson. Folks I know that think most politicians are probably on the take, stupid, or evil; seem to really like Dr. Ben Carson. We have heard much from Dr. Carson in 2015, and the way things are shaping up, it would not be a surprise to hear from him a great deal more in 2016.

Carson is a retired neurosurgeon. He went to the public schools in Detroit, Michigan. Because of his excellence in JROTC, Carson was offered an appointment at West Point. Carson turned down the appointment to go to Yale University where he earned his B.A. degree. Carson received his M.D. from the University of Michigan. He completed his residency in neurosurgery at John Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. And biographical information just as crucial, Carson gives great credit to the Book of Proverbs in the Bible for his success.

By now, many Americans, and even more voters have heard of this modern day "rags to riches" Horatio Alger hero. He was born into a single parent family. He was raised by a very hardworking, loving mother. He was raised in abject poverty in the projects. He began his education in a failing public school. He had a great deal of life's negativity going against him. He could have blamed his family, the government, and God for all of his circumstances; but he chose not to. With a great deal of credit going to his no-nonsense mom, Dr. Ben Carson made a lot of great choices.

Carson did just that. He believed it and he lived it. A real life story that Horatio Alger could not have conjured up and written any better. Carson's faith, hard work, discipline, courage, and consistently making the right choices have made him a role model of what can be done despite the environmental and cultural circumstances. Carson seems to be more of a positive character out of Jimmy Stewart's "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington" movie rather than of the real life "millennial me" generation.

Carson has publicly condemned Obamacare and he even did so in front of President Obama. Because of Carson's swipe at the throne of Obama, some believe he was audited by the IRS in less than six months. The Obama administration has used the IRS against his political enemies in ways that Richard Nixon only dreamed about. Obama's IRS had to clear Dr. Carson of any wrong doings. Carson has also condemned socialized medicine. Dr. Carson knows we must support Israel or America is finished as a world power. Carson disagrees with Obama picking Iran and the ayatollahs over our one true friend in the Middle East, Israel. Carson believes that all lives matter. Dr. Carson believes the babies, not fetuses but babies, lives in the womb matter. Carson has operated many times on babies still in the womb so that they can see daylight soon. Carson believes that he was operating on a human being inside the womb. Carson believes that turning a blind eye to illegal immigration is a country committing suicide. Because of all these many values that Carson believes in, many Americans are beginning to believe in Carson. Carson is an unapologetic, God fearing, flag waving, humble American. Of the Presidents in the last 50 years, Carson most resembles Ronald Reagan in his childhood, his growing up, his being a self made man, and his politics. Of note, Reagan read a lot of Horatio Alger novels when he himself was growing up.

Hopefully, the racial epithets hurled at Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas will not be thrown at Carson. Both the conservative Carson and Thomas have both had an extra burden to bare because of their Republican conservatism. The permanent political class gets very nervous when they are not in control of a candidate for the White House. Carson makes them anxious. Carson is the man that books are written about, movies are made of, and role models are envisioned. Carson, you have a phone call on line one from a Horatio Alger.
Andy Coy, a resident of North Fort Myers, is a former Lee County commissioner.
CINCINNATI — Presidential candidate Ben Carson suggests reducing government regulations as a step toward reducing poverty in places like Cincinnati.

"It might surprise you, but one of the things would be to get rid of the excessive regulation in our country. It drives the prices of everything up," the Republican said in response to an Cincinnati Enquirer question asked during his visit here Wednesday night. "It doesn’t hurt rich people when they go into the store and a bar of soap costs 10 cents more, it hurts the poor person."
He blamed the national debt for keeping interest rates low and making it impossible for poor people to grow their wealth.

“Poor people and middle-class people used to be able to grow their money by putting it in a savings account," Carson said while standing in an alleyway behind The Cincinnatian hotel downtown. "You can’t do that any more. Long-term bonds, nothing — it’s really these policies that are creating the real problem for the poor.

"It’s not, as some people would tell you, the rich people, and if we could just take their money somehow it will be OK," he said. "As long as you have these policies in place, you’re going to still have these problems.”

Carson, one of the top-polling Republicans in the presidential race, visited to speak to the Young Presidents' Organization. He encouraged the group to do things in their spheres of influence to "ensure that the next generation has the same kind of opportunities we’ve had."
This was his first visit to the area since a Sharonville, Ohio, rally in September.
After the event, Carson went to the area near The Cincinnatian before a fundraiser. There, he answered questions about terrorism, foreign policy and immigration.

"We have to recognize that if you have a large group of people coming in from an area where there are a lot of radical extremists, that they will infiltrate them," Carson said of the national debate regarding the acceptance of Syrian refugees that's emerged rapidly since Friday night's terror attacks in Paris.
He argued that any vetting process for refugees adopted at the federal level should be debated publicly.
"We don’t want to do anything that’s going to increase the danger to our citizens, but at the same time we want to be compassionate," he said.

Carson's visit comes as some advisers say he is struggling to grasp the complexities of foreign policy. A story published Tuesday in The New York Times quoted one of Carson’s advisers as saying the retired neurosurgeon, who is making his first run for public office, is having trouble understanding foreign policy despite intense briefings on the subject.
He brushed off these concerns here.
“I’ve been to 57 different countries, I’ve lived abroad, and I have common sense and a brain,” he said, arguing that Hillary Clinton's experience as secretary of state didn't help her avoid problems.

He also laid out his plan for fighting the Islamic State, stating that the United States should formally declare war on the organization that has declared a "caliphate' in portions of Syria and Iraq. Carson also suggested rallying NATO and Middle Eastern allies and if necessary destroying oil fields to cut off the group's revenue.
An Oct. 8 Quinnipiac University poll found Carson to be the No. 2 favorite among Ohio Republicans, backed by 18% of likely Republican voters. The Ohio primary is March 15.

The leading candidate among Ohio Republicans was Donald Trump with 23%; he's scheduled to campaign Monday in Columbus. Ohio governor John Kasich was the third choice in that poll, even among the state's own Republicans, with 13%.
Follow Cameron Knight on Twitter: @ckpj99
Presidential candidate Ben Carson plans to visit northwestern Iowa on Friday before participating in a Republican forum.
The retired neurosurgeon will attend a rally at the Spencer Municipal Airport on Friday afternoon, according to a news release from his campaign.
Later that evening, he is slated to attend the Presidential Family Forum, hosted by the Family Leader, in Des Moines. The event starts at 6:30 p.m.
The campaign appearance marks the first for Carson since Oct. 24, when he spoke at Iowa State University's Alpha Gamma Rho fraternity house then hosted several book-signing stops across the state.
Spencer: 3:40 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. rally at Spencer Municipal Airport, 1965 330th St.
Ben Carson's campaign announced Wednesday that the Republican presidential candidate has secured volunteer organizers in all of Iowa’s 99 counties.
With chairs and co-chairs, the full list of Carson volunteer advocates includes more than 135 names across the Hawkeye State.
Some influential names highlighted by the campaign include former Iowa Sen. James Hahn, of Muscatine County, and Doug Robbins, a member of the Delaware County Iowa Republicans Central Committee.
The county leaders are responsible for recruiting voters and assisting paid campaign staff by coordinating activities and volunteer events, according to campaign aids.

Carson joins a small handful of other Republican candidates — including Rand Paul, Ted Cruz and Scott Walker before he suspended his campaign last month — who have announced endorsements or volunteer coordinators from all 99 counties.
But Carson is the only candidate who also garnered a list of chairs in all 99 counties for his Super PAC before announcing a presidential bid last year.
Ben Carson has a reservoir of support in the Ozarks.

Thousands of people stood in line Thursday at the Mardel Christian & Education Supply store at 1533 E. Battlefield Road, where Carson, a Republican presidential hopeful, signed copies of his latest book. The line to get into the store stretched around the large building as people stood in the dark next to semitrailers and loading docks waiting for Carson's autograph. Meanwhile, in front of the store, crowds of people took selfies posing next to Carson's tour bus.

"I like that he's a real person," said Bobbie Smith, 43, of Richland, who made the hour and 15 minute trip to Springfield with her 73-year-old mother and 13-year-old daughter. "I don't know how to fix all of the problems of the country, but I think we have smart people who can and he's one of them."
The grandmother, Marie Klein, chimed in, "I like that he's a Christian."

Klein also said she respected that Carson, a native of Detroit, came from humble beginnings. Smith said it was her daughter, Blaire, who was the biggest fan of Carson and was the one who pushed the trio to attend the book signing.

In a somewhat unusual, although not unprecedented, move, Carson has interrupted his campaigning to go on a tour promoting "A More Perfect Union," a book on the U.S. Constitution he wrote with his wife.

During Thursday night's signing — Carson's third stop that day — the candidate swiftly signed copies of the book, often looking up to smile at people as they passed through the line and occasionally sharing a quick word with someone.
Ryan Howerton, a 24-year-old graduate student at Missouri State University, said he showed up to support Carson.
"I like — I know nonpolitical politicians are really having a push — I just like the way he comes across. Very genuine," he said. Howerton said he is also a supporter of Marco Rubio.

Thursday was a good day for Carson. He surpassed Donald Trump as the Republican front runner in Iowa, according to a new poll. Carson had support of 28 percent of the Republican caucus-goers in Iowa compared to 20 percent for Trump, a Quinnipiac University poll found, according to a news release on the university's website.
Trumped polled especially well among evangelicals and women, the poll found.
"I like that he is so mellow," 22-year-old Renee Smith said of Carson's speaking style. "Trump is so bombastic."

The Missouri State University student majoring in criminology said Carson appears to have a sincere respect for women, while Trump has made derogatory remarks about some women — which might help explain the polling results.

Renee Smith also said she likes that Carson has not apologized for controversial statements he's made in recent weeks, including that he would likely not support a Muslim for president, and that the Holocaust would have been less successful had German citizens had guns.

"I really like how he hasn't backed down on a lot of his comments, which you know that have gotten backlash. You know about Muslims, Islam. All he does is clarify them. He doesn't back down. It's nice to see for once," she said.

Carson told the News-Leader last week that despite criticism, he doesn't believe supporters will be turned off by his statements. Carson said, "the people absolutely know what I am saying," even if media members considered took his comments as gaffes or considered them inflammatory.
Howerton said he too would have a hard time voting for a Muslim president.
"I don't want to sound prejudiced or anything, but I would have a hard time myself voting for a Muslim president, also," Howerton said. Asked why, Howerton said because of his deep Christian faith.

Among Carson's supporters who spoke with the News-Leader on Thursday, most said they liked the candidate because they thought he would be a good leader and because they respected his backstory, growing up in a poor neighborhood and his successful career in medicine. Few mentioned specific policy initiatives they were excited about.

Renee Smith, the college student, said she feels like the country is "headed in the wrong direction" and that Carson would be a president who could steer it right. Asked what she meant by "wrong direction," Renee Smith said she worried about getting a full-time job after college and worried the same for her brother and cousins. She talked about a general economic uneasiness.

"I'm a millennial. I'm working part time as a cashier. But I don't know what's going to happen after I graduate. I am terrified because I am not sure I am going to be able to find a job. My generation was promised the American Dream. Instead what we get is lack of jobs. We are stuck. So many of us are living at home with our parents and people are calling us lazy. We're not lazy. We just don't have the opportunity. And I feel like that's because of Obama ..." she said.

Bobbie Smith, the mother from Richland, said she was happy that Carson had inspired her daughter to take an interest in politics. While a supporter of the Republican Party, she herself has been disillusioned with many politicians who seem to accomplish little once elected into office, and she doesn't want her daughter to feel that way, she said.

"I don't want to be 40 years old and feel like I have no control or power with my government, you know, like my vote doesn't matter. I want her to feel like her vote matters as well," Bobbie Smith said.

On Nov. 1, Republican presidential candidate Dr. Ben Carson and his wife, Candy, will be appearing at Books-A-Million, 6235 N. Davis Highway, to sign copies of his newly released book, “A More Perfect Union: What We the People Can Do To Reclaim Our Constitutional Liberties.”
According to a news release, the book discusses the basic principles of the Constitution and “how they relate to our everyday lives.” The event begins at 3:30 p.m. and is free and open to the public.
Attendees can purchase copies of Dr. Carson’s books, which he will sign until his scheduled departure time, and get a free “thank you” photo with Dr. Carson that can be downloaded after the event.
Retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson, a leading Republican candidate for president, on Saturday filed his paperwork to be included on Arizona's March 22 presidential preference election ballot.

Carson is the third GOP contender to file for what is commonly referred to as the state's presidential primary, but he was the first here to file in person, entering Arizona Secretary of State Michele Reagan's office with about 10 advisers and Secret Service guards Saturday afternoon.
Carson, dressed in a dark suit and red tie, sauntered into the Phoenix office during a low-key visit in which he waited at the window for a handful of minutes. Reagan processed his forms.
On Friday, representatives of former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush's and U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz's Republican campaigns also filed their papers.
According to Reagan's office, a presidential candidate must either turn in 500 valid signatures from qualified electors or else have already qualified for the primary ballot in two other states.

While in Phoenix, Carson briefly talked with reporters about Friday's terrorist attacks in Paris that left at least 129 people dead and an estimated 352 injured. The Islamic State, also known as ISIS, claimed responsibility for the highly coordinated massacre.

"We're dealing with people who have a mind-set of destruction and a thirst for innocent blood," Carson said. "We really need to take the battle to them. If we don't, they'll continue to expand and they'll be over here."
That battle, he said, would rely on strong leadership.

"We will use whatever we need to use. We may not have to use that many troops, but we do have to demonstrate leadership if we want a real strong coalition to form. It's not going to form unless it has a leader," he said.
He also proposed using American resources and expertise in helping Syrian refugees settle in the Middle East.

"At some point, we just have to start using common sense. It doesn't mean we're not compassionate. But we can use some of our resources and some of our expertise to help them get settled in their area," Carson said. "I think all of the countries there should take them. We should use our influence to convince them to take them."
"We're walking away from American values when we don't use common sense. Americans used to have common sense," he said.

Carson's surprise rise to the top of some GOP polls has prompted greater media scrutiny of his personal biography that has garnered many conservative fans. He also has taken repeated shots from celebrity billionaire Donald Trump, his top rival for Republican front-runner status.
Trump on Thursday ridiculed Carson's personal story of redemption as "crap."
On Saturday, Carson commented on Trump's remarks, saying that he doesn't "get dragged into silly stuff like that."
"It doesn't surprise me that people will do anything they can to try to denigrate someone else and elevate themselves," Carson said. "Isn't that human nature?"
Trump and Carson are virtually tied in the RealClearPolitics website's rolling average of national polls: 24.8 percent for Trump and 24.4 percent for Carson.
Carson previously visited Arizona in August. That trip included a tour of the U.S.-Mexico border.
Ben Carson has surpassed Hillary Clinton as the top fundraiser in Iowa just as polling shows him emerging as the new favorite among Iowa's likely Republican caucusgoers.

More than 900 Iowans have contributed $153,000 to Carson’s campaign through Sept. 30, according to a Des Moines Register analysis of the latest financial reports filed with the Federal Elections Commission
That puts him ahead of Clinton, who was the leading fundraiser for the quarter ending in June. According to the filings, Clinton has so far received donations from 538 Iowans totaling $111,600.
A Des Moines Register/Bloomberg Politics Iowa Poll released last week shows Carson has also surged to the top of the Republican pack in Iowa, replacing previous front-runner Donald Trump.

The poll, which mirrors others released in the past week, shows 28 percent of respondents listing Carson as their first choice for president. That’s up from 18 percent in August, and well ahead of Trump, who fell from 23 percent to 19 percent.
DATABASE: Review contributions by candidate, contributor, city

Doug Bergantzel, who runs a small auto parts business in Council Bluffs, has given to Carson on three occasions, beginning with a $100 donation at the end of August and two subsequent $50 donations in September.
Bergantzel said his top three contenders are Carson, Trump and former Hewlett-Packard CEO Carly Fiorina.

“I like them because they’re not sold-out politicians,” he said. “Anybody but (former Florida Gov. Jeb) Bush. I mean, with Bush you just get more of Washington. You get the same old group with Bush. You get the Washington insiders.”
Bergantzel said he hasn’t given to Trump’s campaign for one simple reason: Trump hasn’t asked him yet. So far, Trump has said he’s willing to self-finance his run for the presidency.

The Carson campaign was quick to try to capitalize on recent poll results, sending out fundraising emails shortly after results were made public. His campaign is offering anyone who donates $5 or more a chance to join Carson for a one-on-one lunch on the campaign trail.
About a third of all contributions Iowans made to the Carson campaign came in the month of September, which is notable because Carson didn’t make any stops in Iowa that month.
Ryan Rhodes, an Iowa strategist with the Carson campaign, said the campaign is focusing on its organizational ground game.
“I think you see an uptick there because we’re able to follow up on the people who got involved" at events and campaign stops, Rhodes said.

Mack Shelley, chair of the political science department at Iowa State University, said more notable than the dollar amount is the number of individuals who have given to Carson versus Clinton. Carson has tallied nearly double the number of individual donors as Clinton: 911 compared with 538.
"If you have a lot of money coming in, and it comes from a lot of different people, I think that’s really eloquent testimony that you’ve got broad support," he said.

He also referenced Citizens United, the 2010 U.S. Supreme Court ruling that allows corporations and unions to spend unlimited amounts urging the election or defeat of candidates. Even with unlimited giving to super political action committees and other independent expenditure organizations, cash flow for the candidate's actual campaign organization is still critical, he said.

Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, who was at one point the Republican front-runner in Iowa, dropped out of the race following cash problems, even though he still had a well-funded super PAC supporting his candidacy.
"It isn’t sufficient just to have real top-dollar contributors," Shelley said.
Bergantzel said he plans to continue giving to Carson throughout the race whenever his family finances allow.
In total, 3,124 Iowans gave to candidates during the first three quarters, totaling nearly $668,000.

Behind Carson and Clinton were Texas U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz, who recorded more than $67,700 from 538 Iowans, and Vermont U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders, with about 550 Iowa contributions totaling about $57,400.
Sanders, who is narrowing the gap between himself and Clinton, according to the latest Iowa Poll, still lags Clinton in fundraising here, the data show.
Among the candidates who raised the least in Iowa were South Carolina U.S. Sen. Lindsey Graham, who raised $3,550 from 11 Iowans, and Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal, who raised $4,420 from eight Iowans.
DATABASE: Review contributions by candidate, contributor, city

New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie also reported fewer than 10 contributions to his campaign. Former New York Gov. George Pataki, a Republican, and former Rhode Island Gov. Lincoln Chafee, a Democrat who dropped out of the race Oct. 23, listed no Iowa money raised.
Carson and other candidates may well have raised more money in Iowa than is reflected in the reports, however. They are required to itemize only individual contributions of $200 or more.

Across the country, for example, Carson reported $11.7 million in itemized individual contributions through September, compared with $19.6 million for that same period that were not itemized and can’t be traced to specific donors or states.
Overall, contributions to candidates this election cycle are down significantly from this point in 2007, a year that saw a similar number of candidates competing in Iowa.

In the first three quarters of 2007, candidates had raised about $1.2 million from more than 2,600 Iowans, close to double this cycle's $668,000. At that point, Tom Vilsack had outraised then-U.S. Sen. Barack Obama more than two to one, pulling in $287,500 compared with Obama’s $118,900.
On the Republican side, Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney had raised about $153,200 from Iowans.

Gayle Alberda, a visiting political science professor at Drake University, said it’s possible that with so many Republican candidates, Iowans are waiting to write their checks until they’ve had more time to sort out which candidates they do and don’t like.

“It’s really hard — especially on the Republican side with how many candidates there are and who’s dropping out and who’s not,” she said. “Just to secure those donations you need to be viable — and you’re not viable unless you get donations.”
DATABASE: Review contributions by candidate, contributor, city
Additionally, 2007 was “really unique,” she said, with Clinton and Obama each making historic runs for the White House.
“I think by nature that alone drove individuals who might not be readily involved to become involved,” she said.

Shelley, the ISU political scientist, said Clinton's perceived dominance, especially early, may have inhibited Democrats from giving, either because they didn't believe her campaign needed need the money, or thought contributing to someone else seemed pointless.
But Clinton and others will need those dollars in order to run a viable campaign, he said.

"To be able to maintain the appearance — and it’s often the reality too — of a strong vibrant campaign, you have to have the dollars coming in," he said. "Whether there’s a direct translation between dollars and votes is a real different matter of course."
MORE:

It’s a small man who delights in the misfortune of others, but I can’t help myself. As much as I regret that he is being forced to deal with the vileness emanating from Democrats, I am having a blast watching the political left try to deal with Dr. Ben Carson.

After months of attempting to marginalize him as a fringe candidate who would fade quickly in the crowded Republican presidential field, liberals are having to come to grips with the reality that Carson is a legitimate contender. And it isn’t going over well.

Why? It proves that liberals’ habit of screaming “racist” at any person who opposed the presidency of Barack Obama has been as wrong as it was despicable. It turns out that Republicans don’t mind electing a black president – they just haven’t enjoyed a liberal one.

But Carson’s rise stirs a more primal reaction on the left. Progressives are furious that an accomplished black man would dare to reject liberal ideology, because doing so threatens to undo the engine of exploitation that fuels Democratic political power.

As the party of big government, liberals have enacted policies that have locked blacks into failing inner-city schools, ended scholarship programs designed to help black children excel, facilitated a dangerous dependency that has led to an epidemic of fatherless black homes, encouraged an influx of illegal immigrants who have disproportionately deprived young black men of jobs, and funded a “family planning” strategy that has disproportionately harmed black communities.

If you are tempted to excuse those offenses as unintentional or coincidental, note that both Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton are disciples of leftist icon Saul Alinsky. It was Alinsky who articulated the strategy that in order to control a group of people, they “must feel so frustrated, so defeated, so lost, so futureless in the prevailing system that they are willing.” While gutting the black community with their policies, Democrats have managed to portray themselves as blacks’ only hope.

Alinsky continued, “The despair is there; now it's up to us to go in and rub raw the sores of discontent, galvanize them for radical social change. We'll give them a way to participate in the democratic process, a way to exercise their rights as citizens and strike back at the establishment that oppresses them.” If this doesn’t describe the behavior of Democratic political activists, I don’t know what does.

But that scheme is upended by the emergence of a self-made member of the oppressed group – one who rose to prominence without the crutch of liberal social programs, and who articulates the inherent danger and destructive nature of their bloated existence. Meet Ben Carson, a man born into the crucible of inner-city strife, but who escaped the cycle of poverty to become a brilliant neurosurgeon.

Carson’s message of a smaller government, self-reliance and Christian faith offer a stark contrast to the grievance mongering and victim mentality promoted for decades by Democrats. The good doctor praises the existence of government safety nets but deplores the use of dependency programs for political ends. Consequently, the same people that have claimed for years to be the champions of minorities are doing all they can to stop one from succeeding.

When you come to believe that people must think a certain way simply because of their skin color, and you despise them when they don’t, you are the one with the race problem. That is the uncomfortable truth Ben Carson’s candidacy is revealing, and it’s why the left will stop at nothing to destroy him.
Heck is a speaker, author and teacher. Follow him @peterheck, email peter@peterheck.com or visit www.peterheck.com.
LITTLE ROCK - Republican presidential hopeful Ben Carson is returning to Arkansas to headline a campaign rally at a West Memphis school.
The retired neurosurgeon's campaign website said he'll appear at a rally at West Memphis High School on Friday night and talk about his vision for the country's future.
This is the second time Carson has campaigned in Arkansas in recent months. Carson campaigned in Little Rock in August with a rally outside the state Capitol.

Carson is among several GOP hopefuls who have visited the state since Arkansas lawmakers moved up next year's primary from May to March 1. Other candidates who have campaigned in the state include former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee, former Hewlett-Packard CEO Carly Fiorina, Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and billionaire Donald Trump.
(Copyright 2015 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.)
Ben Carson voiced frustration toward perceptions about his foreign-policy knowledge at a campaign stop in Wilton Sunday afternoon.
He said other people, including President Barack Obama, have used his talking points and strategy, while claiming the retired neurosurgeon lacks experience in foreign affairs.

“They say, ‘Carson doesn’t know anything about foreign affairs,’ but yet everybody picks up on all this stuff I say, including President Obama, and start using it for themselves,” he said during a speech in Wilton.
He offered one particular example of a strategy he’s outlined “for multiple months.”

“If they take the fight to (ISIS) over there, we’re much less likely to have to fight them over here. And I find it a little frustrating I say things like that and nobody ever pays any attention,” he said.
The retired neurosurgeon scheduled three events in Iowa Sunday afternoon.

The visit comes on the heels of pointed concerns about national security and foreign policy with the rising threat of ISIS — topics that one of Carson's military advisers told The New York Times this week the former brain surgeon is struggling to grasp. Carson also failed to voice specifics in a recent Fox News interview when pressed on whom America should align with for an international coalition against ISIS.
Those attending two Carson events Sunday expressed mixed views about his ability to tackle foreign policy.
Out of 12 people interviewed, most acknowledged a lack of foreign experience but also voiced confidence in Carson’s ability to learn and surround himself with experts.
Follow Iowa Caucus news, photos, videos with Iowa Caucuses App: iPhone or iPad | Android
Five people said they see Carson’s foreign policy as a potential weakness or concern.

“I think he has a ways to go in his learning. He’s a smart man but he hasn’t been able to absorb this much this fast … on a lot of things, but definitely foreign policy,” said Dee Vanderhoel, 75, a Republican from Iowa City.
A younger voter, Zeke Walker, 19, voiced a similar opinion after hearing from Carson and Carly Fiorina in Wilton — where both candidates spoke at the Kaufmann Family Barbecue on Sunday.

“(Fiorina’s) actually laid out a numbered list of what she’d do with foreign policy,” said Walker, a political science student at Muscatine Community College. “I haven’t really gotten anything from (Carson) about that that has really wowed me.”

During his speech in Wilton, Carson said he would push to cut off resources feeding ISIS, including seizing oil fields in the East. He also voiced support for creating an international government coalition to target the group and help resettle refugees.
Carson did not mention the recent attacks in Paris or strategy against ISIS at an earlier stop in a church in Tipton on Sunday.
His speeches at both events opened by telling of "bulletproof George Washington," emphasizing how God protected the first U.S. president and Army general from musket balls.
Also visit: DesMoinesRegister.com/IowaCaucuses | Candidate tracker and calendar in Iowa | Sign up for Caucuses Newsletter
He followed up the story in Tipton with a personal anecdote about falling asleep while driving with his wife Candy in November 1972.

His life flashed before his eyes when he awoke, zooming across the rumble strip, Carson said. He credits his and Candy’s survival, like Washington's, to divine protection because "God kept us alive for a reason."
It’s the type of appeal — focused on personal life story, faith and morality — that most Carson supporters highlight when asked why they back the retired neurosurgeon.

Three Republican voters in Tipton said Carson tops their list of potential candidates because of his integrity. They said his emphasis on morality is the most important factor for foreign policy and military action.
“He would look at it from a moral (perspective) of ‘what’s right and what should we do,' ” said Denise Cartwright, a resident of Tipton who identified as a Libertarian.
Another Tipton resident Mary Bormann said she believes Carson will trust military leaders.
“He’s somebody who’s going to have enough common sense to listen to the military people who do know,” Bormann said.
SETTING: Small rural church in Tipton; annual Kaufmann Family Barbecue and fundraiser for Iowa state Rep. Bobby Kaufmann at community center in Wilton.
CROWD: Forty to 50 people in Tipton; roughly 400 at Wilton fundraiser, where Carson spoke as well as Carly Fiorina and several local and state Republican officials.

REACTION: More subdued, older crowd with some applause for Carson’s 10-minute speech in Tipton. Several rounds of applause throughout 23-minute speech in Wilton, with standing ovation at the end plus three questions from the audience.
WHAT’S NEXT: This was a one-day trip to Iowa with three stops for Carson. He also appeared in Iowa Friday for just one stop at the Presidential Family Forum in Des Moines.
“Beware of the false prophets, who come to you in sheep’s clothing, but inwardly are ravenous wolves. You will know them by their fruits.”
— Matthew 7:15-16

Major newspaper editorials and some columnists have their knickers in a twist over remarks by Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson. Appearing last Sunday on “Meet the Press,” Carson was asked by host Chuck Todd whether he believes Islam is consistent with the Constitution. “No, I don’t,” he said. “I would not advocate that we put a Muslim in charge of this nation.” Asked whether he could vote for a Muslim for Congress, Carson said Congress is a different story, but that it “depends on who that Muslim is and what their policies are.”

Carson critics are quick to mention Article VI of the Constitution, which prohibits a “religious test” for office, but that means no one can be barred from office because of their faith; it does not and could not prevent citizens from voting for or against someone for religious reasons.

Two years ago, The U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom reported that 10 of the 15 “worst violators of religious freedom” in the world are nations in which Islam is the dominant religion.

If you prefer the thoughts of a cultural icon, consider what singer Art Garfunkel said. As reported on DailyMail.com, Garfunkel noted that Muslims are transforming Europe. He referenced “Reflections of the Revolution in Europe,” a 2009 book by Christopher Caldwell, which argues, “that mass immigration by Muslims is altering the culture of Europe because of their reluctance to join the culture of their new homelands.” The book claims Muslims do not so much enhance European culture as supplant it, and are “patiently conquering Europe’s cities, street by street.”

Is that bigotry, or reality? Is it bigotry to quote what various Islamic leaders say are their intentions when it comes to establishing a worldwide caliphate and replacing the U.S. Constitution with Sharia Law, or is it a warning we should take seriously and respond to as we would react to any other invasion?

“Mina” (not her real name to protect her family) is a U.S. citizen and longtime friend who was born in Tehran and still has family there. She wrote me about the intentions of the mullahs and their nuclear deal with the U.S. and five other nations: “The mullahs are buying time … (to) finish their nuclear program. Americans underestimate these people. It will be Hezbollah, ISIS, or al-Qaida doing their dirty work. They will give them the nuclear bomb. They are very shrewd. They’ll sit back and watch.”

“Mina” says the Iranian regime has been a huge supporter of President Obama, whose name in Persian, she notes, translates as “he is with us.” She asks why Arab and Muslim countries don’t take in the migrants now fleeing their native lands for Europe (and now thanks to President Obama the U.S.). It’s a good question and the answer ought to be obvious to anyone not afraid of being labeled a “bigot.” They support the invasion.

While not all Muslims are terrorists, Breitbart recently revealed a startling statistic. “In a recent survey conducted by AlJazeera.net, the website for the Al Jazeera Arabic television channel,” it writes, “respondents overwhelmingly support the Islamic State terrorist group, with 81 percent voting “YES” on whether they approved of ISIS’s conquests in the region.” Eighty-one percent.

We are at war with a radical ideology that wishes to destroy the West and drastically alter our way of life. That is what Ben Carson was getting at when he made his remarks about a Muslim president in the White House.

Retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson, already under fire for his foreign policy acumen, is now being criticized for his grasp of history, particularly that of Thomas Jefferson.

In a C-SPAN interview broadcast Sunday, Carson praised Jefferson as a Founding Father who “tried to craft our Constitution in a way that it would control peoples’ natural tendencies and control the natural growth of the government.”

Jefferson, however, did not participate in the development of the U.S. Constitution during a 1787 convention. As Carson himself pointed out in his book A More Perfect Union, Jefferson was serving as U.S. minister to France at that time.
The Washington Post, which reported on Carson’s flub, also noted that “it’s not the first time Carson has abused Jefferson’s history.” The Post reported:

“Thomas Jefferson himself said, ‘Gun control works great for the people who are law-abiding citizens and it does nothing for the criminals, and all it does is put the people at risk,’” he told Fox’s Neil Cavuto after the shootings at Umpqua Community College in Roseburg, Ore. in early October. Jefferson never said that.
WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. – Presidential hopeful Dr. Ben Carson spoke at a church in Winston-Salem Tuesday afternoon. Monday, the Republican candidate was in Randolph County touring Victory Junction.

Dr. Carson, a retired neurosurgeon, is closing in on businessman Donald Trump in the most recent polls. Twenty percent of Republican primary voters said they would pick Carson as president while 19 percent said they’d chose Trump. Similar results in the most recent Elon University poll. Trump led with 22 percent with Dr. Carson trailing just one percentage point.
READ:Dr. Carson Gaining Momentum, Trump's Tax Plan

Dr. Carson, a passionate Christian, spoke at the Berean Baptist Church in Winston-Salem. Several hundred people waited in the rain to hear what the "non-politician" had to say about the state of our union.
"I believe the mindset of America is shifting. That we are wanting a real effective change and the politicians and the system that are in there now is doing it," said Jason Cirone, Asheboro resident.
Cirone and his friend arrived at Berean Baptist Church at 9:00 a.m. and were the second and third people in line.
"This is the first time there is a candidate that I actually believe in."
Randy Swatta lives in Pinehurst but made the 90 mile trip to Winston-Salem to hear Dr. Carson.
Although he says he admires "the heck out of [that] man," he was undecided before the speech.

"I don’t know if it’s 100-percent made up, I know that I would back him right until the bitter end. I think his lack of being a politician could be his downfall unfortunately. I’d like to think not but we live in a political world," said Swatta.

Ben Carson refused to back away from his controversial remarks on mass shootings that lit up the gun control debate this week. The GOP presidential candidate argued that everyone should attack a massive shooter and he would sacrifice his life if he were face-to-face with a gunman. He said he'd rather see a body with bullet holes over gun control.

"I want to plant in people's minds what to do in a situation like this because unfortunately this is probably not going to be the last time this happens," he said in an interview on "CBS This Morning."

Less than a week after the mass shooting on the Umpqua Community College campus in Oregon,presidential candidates have been addressing gun control and mental health issues. But Carson's latest comments defending the right to bear arms may be the most controversial, reports CBS News correspondent Julianna Goldman.
Watch CBS This Mornings segment on Ben Carson's comments
"I would ask everybody to attack the gunman because he can only shoot one of us at a time. That way, we don't all wind up dead," he told ABC News while chuckling on Tuesday.
"The accusation there, Dr. Carson, is that you appeared tone deaf and that you seemed callous in the laughter about a massacre and what you would have done," Fox News' Megyn Kelly said.
"I'm laughing at them and their silliness," Carson responded.
"Who?" Kelly asked.

"The people asking that question. Of course, you know, if everybody attacks that gunman, he's not going to be able to kill everybody. But if you sit there and let him shoot you one by one, you're all going to be dead," Carson said.
When asked if he was judging the victims, Carson said he was looking at "the big picture."

"Not judging them at all. But, you know, these incidents continue to occur. I doubt that this will be the last one. I want to plant the seed in people's minds so that if this happens again, you know, they don't all get killed," he said.

On "CBS This Morning," Carson said that the case of Chris Mintz, the army veteran who was shot seven times while charging the shooter and ultimately saved lives, "verifies what I'm saying," although he did not know Mintz was when first asked about him.
"That's exactly what should be done and if everybody does that, the likelihood of him being able to kill as many people diminishes quite significantly," Carson said.
He deflected another question about the impossibility of knowing how he'd behave in that situation.

"We live in a culture now where people decide that everything you say - 'we need to set up battle lines,' and 'we need to get on this side of it or that side of it,' rather than of collectively trying to figure out how we solve the problem," he said. "It's sort of an immature attitude but it seems to be something that's rampant in America today."

As for seeking solutions to the problem of mass shootings in America, Carson advocated for studying the lives of each person who has carried out a mass shooting to see if there are patterns or early warning signs that would identify people who might be dangerous in the future.

"I think we have to for instance empower the psychiatrist, the psychologist, and number these cases," he said. "These people have already been working with mental health professionals, but nothing was done about it and we have to be able to move to the next step, not just recognizing that they're mentally ill but being able to take the appropriate interventional steps."

He said that the U.S. should "absolutely" look for a "mechanism" to keep weapons away from people that had been declared dangerous by a mental health professional, but added, "We need to study all the possibilities, and we cannot do anything that compromises the Second Amendment."
He also appeared on ABC's "The View" where he reiterated that kindergarten teachers should be armed with guns in their classrooms.
"Not all kindergarten teachers. I said people who are trained and understand all the implications and you're obviously not going to have a weapon sitting on the teacher's desk," Carson said.
The weapon would be secured in a place where kids can't get to it," he added.
"If the gunman comes in with an AK-45, or AR-15, how fast can that teacher go to the locked drawer and get that gun?" co-host Joy Behar asked.

"I want that teacher trained in diversionary tactics and whatever needs to be done in order to get there and I want there to be other people in that school who also know how to get to that gun," Carson said.
Carson stated that even his experience as a doctor removing bullets from victims of gun violence has reinforced his belief in the Second Amendment.

In a Facebook question and answer session he wrote: "There is no doubt that this senseless violence is breathtaking - but I never saw a body with bullet holes that was more devastating than taking the right to arm ourselves away."
Other Republican candidates responded to the latest mass shooting with staunch opposition to stricter gun laws.
"Stuff happens. There's always a crisis," Jeb Bush said.
In Iowa, Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton mocked Jeb Bush's remark.
"This isn't stuff that happens. We let it happen, and we have to act," Clinton said.

President Obama is going to Oregon to meet with the families of victims Friday. Some protests are expected, and Carson was asked if he would do the same as president. He responded probably not and suggested it would be politicizing the tragedy.
On "CBS This Morning," he said that if he were to go, his visit would attract less negative attention than Mr. Obama's "because I wouldn't be picking and choosing which groups I sympathize with."
Carson stated that even his experience as a doctor removing bullets from victims of gun violence has reinforced his belief in the Second Amendment.

Though he once supported a ban on military-style assault weapons, Carson's views have changed over the years, and he addressed his change of heart in his new book, "A More Perfect Union." On "CBS This Morning," he said the drafters of the Constitution "recognized that things would change, that we would become a more modern society," he said. "But we have to recognize that it was the principles that were important."

Carson said that the amendment was written to allow people to assist the military in case of an invasion and to protect themselves from an overly aggressive government. Arguing that people cannot have weapons that have become more advanced "violates that principle."

Carly vs. Hillary

USA TODAY’s article can’t be serious when it claims that Carly Fiorina’s campaign will take a hit if Hillary Clinton is the Democratic nominee because gender will not be an issue (“Carly Fiorina’s gender may not be asset in 2016 race”). Up until now, being female is Hillary’s only asset. Carly will eat Hillary’s lunch if the two ever have to square off in a debate, and it will be Hillary losing support from women voters.

Ben Carson’s comment that a Muslim should never be president recalls the criticism of John F. Kennedy (“Whether a candidate is Muslim shouldn't matter: #tellusatoday”).

Critics claimed that a Catholic should never be president because true-believing Catholics acknowledge allegiance to the pope as the representative of Jesus Christ on earth, and that a president’s submitting to the authority of a foreign leader would compromise the integrity and independence of the USA.

We recognize such comments as political propaganda, appealing to the worst elements of anti-Catholic bigotry. Kennedy's critics were wrong then, just as Carson’s appeal to anti-Muslim bigots is wrong now.
